item.title: George Floyd: Thousands protest against racism across US
item.description: Peaceful rallies are held in major cities on the 12th day of protests sparked by George Floyd's death.

item.title: Large anti-racism protests across UK
item.description: Demonstrations sparked by the death of George Floyd have taken place in towns and cities across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Places of worship to reopen for private prayer
item.description: Churches, mosques and synagogues have been closed since lockdown restrictions started in March.

item.title: 'Billions of people' to feel virus economic impact
item.description: World Bank President David Malpass says billions of people will have their livelihoods affected.

item.title: Two Buffalo policemen charged for shoving 75-year-old protester
item.description: The officers filmed pushing a man, 75, to the ground have been charged with second degree-assault.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I wore a disguise to see my twins in lockdown'
item.description: An oil worker who was in quarantine wore a disguise so he could watch his children from a distance.

item.title: D-Day anniversary: Emotional surprise for veteran in lockdown
item.description: Coronavirus disrupted Harry Billinge's D-Day plans. But he got to meet a face from his past instead.

item.title: Coronavirus: NHS trust bosses not consulted over new face mask rules
item.description: Hospital bosses in England felt "in the dark" over changes to policies on face masks and visitors.

item.title: George Floyd death: Australians defy virus in mass anti-racism rallies
item.description: Protesters march in support of George Floyd and indigenous Australians despite coronavirus warnings.

item.title: NFL says players' protests during national anthem should be allowed
item.description: The National Football League previously banned its players from dropping to one knee before games.

item.title: Coronavirus: Far-right Rome protest turns briefly violent
item.description: A rally by extremists and football fans over the government's response ended in clashes with police.

item.title: Kameko stuns Pinatubo to win 2,000 Guineas at Newmarket
item.description: Kameko inflicts a first defeat on Pinatubo to win the 2,000 Guineas, the first British Classic of the season.

item.title: Sir Tom Jones turns 80: Singer shares 'tremendous' memories
item.description: The singing legend, who is celebrating his 80th birthday, shares memories of his life and career.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Relaxed Covid rules and Black Lives Matter march
item.description: Protests across the UK feature prominently on several of the front pages, plus new Covid-19 warnings.

item.title: Meet the street artist making us smile during the pandemic
item.description: David Zinn is a professional chalk artist who's on a mission to show that you don’t need fancy equipment to draw.

item.title: In pictures: Global protests against racism and police brutality
item.description: Sparked by the death of George Floyd in the US, thousands gather globally to say black lives matter.

item.title: Discovering Colombia's rare flora and fauna
item.description: An expedition of top UK botanists into previously unexplored rainforest in Colombia found rare species.

item.title: Money advice: Single parents in lockdown
item.description: Single parents' finances are often tight and they face a particularly high risk of poverty.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your pictures on the theme of 'home-made'
item.description: Our readers reveal the view some of the things they have made while at home during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus face mask lights up with moving mouth shapes
item.description: A games designer creates a face mask that shows animated mouth shapes as you speak.

item.title: How the NFL made its U-turn on kneeling
item.description: Four years after Colin Kaepernick first kneeled during the US national anthem, the NFL says it was "wrong" for not allowing players to protest.

item.title: Your coronavirus lockdown confessions
item.description: From the funny to the outright rule breaks, people open up about the moments they might rather forget.

item.title: Coronavirus: Living lockdown in an empty four-star hotel
item.description: An army of staff moved into Britain's hotels during lockdown, but what comes next is anyone's guess.

item.title: George Floyd killing: Why I decided not to watch the video
item.description: For many black people, videos featuring the killing of other black people can be deeply traumatic.

item.title: Coronavirus: The chaplains at the front line of end-of-life care
item.description: How are hospital and hospice chaplains managing to provide comfort for dying patients?

item.title: Coronavirus: Paris returns to cafe life with new normal
item.description: Unrecognisable by its emptiness during lockdown, Paris rediscovers its raison d'être.

item.title: George Floyd: Why are companies speaking up this time?
item.description: The outpouring of support for protesters from corporate America is a marked shift.

item.title: Back-to-school diary: ‘You can throw the ball, but no-one can catch it’
item.description: When 11-year-old Carl returned to primary school this week almost everything had changed.

item.title: Meet Gracey: The pop star who lost her voice as her career took off
item.description: Gracey had just released her debut single when her voice vanished. Here's what happened next.

item.title: Racism is a pandemic - Joshua speaks at Black Lives Matter march
item.description: Britain's world heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua describes racism as a "pandemic" at a Black Lives Matter march.

item.title: No positive results in latest Premier League coronavirus tests
item.description: There were no positive results for coronavirus from 1,195 tests in the latest round of testing in the Premier League.

item.title: US Open coronavirus protocols extreme - Djokovic
item.description: World number one Novak Djokovic calls the coronavirus safety protocols, planned in order for the US Open to take place "extreme".

item.title: Bayern move to within two wins of Bundesliga title
item.description: Bayern Munich need a maximum of two wins from their final four games to clinch an eighth straight Bundesliga title after coming from behind to beat Bayer Leverkusen.

item.title: Burgess criticism of Fords 'strange and confusing'
item.description: Criticism of Mike and George Ford by ex-England international Sam Burgess is "strange and confusing", says Leicester Tigers head coach Geordan Murphy.

item.title: Sunday's football gossip: Real make £71m bid for Leverkusen's Havertz
item.description: Real Madrid make Havertz bid, Everton lead Rabiot chase, Chelsea set to offload several players, plus more.

item.title: Missing three drugs tests is 'normal' - world champion Naser given provisional ban
item.description: World 400m champion Salwa Eid Naser is given a provisional suspension for failing to make herself available for anti-doping tests.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are to become compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: You can now meet more people and play certain non-contact sports in the UK - but what are they?

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Can I start a new relationship? And other questions
item.description: Starting a new relationship is difficult during the current crisis, but not impossible.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are the first to go back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England in June, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: George Floyd death: Myleene Klass recalls racist abuse
item.description: The musician posted on Instagram describing the abuse she suffered because of her Filipino heritage.

item.title: Women urged not to ignore chest pain during coronavirus pandemic
item.description: Melanie Connell, who underwent a triple bypass, urges women not to be afraid of seeking medical help.

item.title: My Money: 'Our alternative quarantine holiday'
item.description: Alyssa Hulme from Utah in the US takes us through her weekly spending during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Why does Covid-19 make some healthy young people really sick?
item.description: Dr John Wright tells the story of Marium Zameer, who became very unwell with Covid-19 despite being young and healthy.

item.title: 'Scorching-hot hacked computer burned my hand'
item.description: Student's computer overheated after it was hit with a "crypto-jacking" attack.

item.title: The 100-year wound that Hungary cannot forget
item.description: Hungary lost two-thirds of its territory in the 1920 Trianon treaty and now aims to revive its past.

item.title: The Somali atheist activists who get death threats
item.description: Ayaanle and Kahaa work online to help Somalis who have views that do not square with tradition.
